Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
This project will pursue experiments to investigate fundamental aspects of the behavior of matter in low dimensions, such as the dynamics of phase transitions in one or two dimensions. It will also investigate methodically the interactions between atoms adsorbed on a carbon surface and electrons in that surface, which is of wide-reaching relevance to uses of graphitic carbon in sensing, filtration, and storage of gases and of electrical charge. The technique used is to adsorb atomic and molecular layers on individual single-walled carbon nanotubes suspended like miniature guitar strings. The change in vibrational frequency due to mass loading yields the density of atoms to near atomic precision while the effect on the current along the nanotube simultaneously reveals the effect of the atoms on the electrons with better than single-electron precision. The approach will in due course be extended to lower temperatures where exotic quantum fluid and solid behavior may occur confined to the cylindrical geometry of the nanotube surface, and also to graphene and other substrates. The project will support the education of two PhD students and several undergraduates in the wide range of techniques and principles of nanoscale physics and nanotechnology.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
Carbon materials play crucial roles in many technologies, such as filtering, gas storage, and lithium ion batteries, which rely on the interactions of the surface of the carbon with atoms and molecules. Those interactions are complex and surprisingly poorly understood. This project will pursue experiments on the nanoscale that will allow far more precise and methodical determination and understanding of the interactions than has been possible before. The technique involves exposing carbon-nanotube "nanoguitar transistors" and later graphene "nanodrums" to gases at carefully controlled temperature and pressure. By measuring the change in pitch of the nanoguitar or drum, the number of atoms stuck to the surface can be accurately measured, while at the same time by measuring changes in the electrical resistance the interaction with the electrons can be determined with extraordinary precision. On the other hand, the same techniques will be employed at very low temperatures to investigate the fundamental physics of superfluidity and quantum confinement of matter restricted to the surface of a long thin cylinder. The project will be carried out by two PhD students and several undergraduates who will be familiarized with the wide range of techniques and principles of nanoscale physics and nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We measured and analyzed the physical adsorption of several rare gases and simple molecules on single-wall closed-end suspended carbon nanotubes (SWNT) and on individual graphene sheets, and succeeded in obtaining low temperature, high resolution adsorption isotherms of several gases on one, two and three layer graphene devices. The project resulted in the publication of an article in Nature Physics, and the Physics PhD dissertations of Haochun Lee and Boris Dzyubenko. Specific details, described so far in Dr. Dzyubenko's dissertation, are the subject of two articles currently in preparation.

Experimental:

1. Nanotubes. The nanotubes were grown on pre-deposited electrodes (source and drain) across an etched trench with another electrode at the bottom of the trench (gate) as reported earlier. The resonance frequency decreases when mass is adsorbed on the SWNT surface , giving high mass resolution (tens of atoms in our case). We later found that the electrical conductance is also a function of mass adsorption.

2. Three, two and one layer graphene devices. The graphene layers were obtained by exfoliation and transfered using the polymer stamp technique onto prepared wafers across a trench preplated with platinum electrodes (source and drain). Some wafers had a preplated electrode at the bottom of the trench (local gate), others used the silicon substrate. Three, two and one layer suspended graphene devices with both surfaces exposed, and single layer devices capped on one side with several deposited layers of nBN were fabricated (over 30 devices total). We measured the electrical conductance (G) of the two-terminal devices as a function of adsorbate (Ne, Ar, Kr and Xe), pressure, temperature and current annealing (cleaning) of the devices, and imaged by atomic force microscopy.

Cleaning the substrate and impact on previous measurements:  We obtained G vs. P isotherms with features which could be exactly correlated to those of the same gases adsorbed on very clean crystalline graphite, after annealing by applying a DC current which heated the suspended center portion (see image). The pressure at which the riser in the isotherm first appeared was two orders of magnitude higher than expected. Final results on physical adsorption were obtained on these cleaned devices. The most likely contaminant is residual organics from processing and organic material present in the atmosphere. These results imply that for 27 or the 30 suspended nanotube devices we studied their surfaces were also totally or partially contaminated. An example of the very high quality phase behavior observed on cleaned graphene is shown in the image.

Outcomes: 

A very accurate measurement of the binding energies of Ar and Kr on SWNT device #30 at very low coverage was obtained by noting the linearity of the mass adsorption (frequency) vs. pressure isotherms over a range of temperatures suitable to each gas. This last year we verified that many of our earlier devices give very close to the same binding energy at coverages below 0.06 monolayer.

Cleaned two and three layer graphene devices generate conductance vs. pressure isotherms that can be mapped onto isotherms of the same gases at the same temperatures and pressures on single crystal and exfoliated graphite. The isotherms on single layer graphene devices show, when compared with a single layer graphene capped with nBN, the very small shift in pressures corresponding to the adsorption of gas on both side of the graphene, The extra thickness makes the adsorbed layer on the hBN invisible to the layer adsorbed on the graphene.

We obtained several new results: 

1. We detected quasi-one-dimensional phase transitions on the surfaces of individual carbon nanotubes

2. We quantified the interactions between the adsorbates and the electrons in the nanotube substrate

3. We measured critical behavior and fluctuations in this quasi-1D system

4. We detected the adsorption and phases of inert molecules absorbed on individual 1-, 2, 3-layer graphene and graphene on hBN substrates using the conductance, which has not been done before

5. We observed a dramatic effect of commensurate phases likely due to coherent scattering of the electrons

6. We constructed the phase diagram of commensurate nitrogen with unprecedented accuracy

7. We detected novel double-layer phases that occur when commensurate arrangements occur simultaneously on both sides of a sheet of suspended graphene, leading to domains and hysteresis

8. We detected the presence of a uniform adsorbed hydrocarbon film on graphene exposed to air which is likely to be omnipresent.

Other participants, outreach:

Graduate student Joshua Kahn and six undergraduate students also participated in the project.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We measured and analyzed the physical adsorption of several rare gases and simple molecules on single-wall closed-end suspended carbon nanotubes (SWNT) and on individual graphene sheets, and succeeded in obtaining low temperature, high resolution adsorption isotherms of several gases on one, two and three layer graphene devices. The project resulted in the publication of an article in Nature Physics, and the Physics PhD dissertations of Haochun Lee and Boris Dzyubenko. Specific details, described so far in Dr. Dzyubenko's dissertation, are the subject of two articles currently in preparation. Experimental: 1. Nanotubes. The nanotubes were grown on pre-deposited electrodes (source and drain) across an etched trench with another electrode at the bottom of the trench (gate) as reported earlier. The resonance frequency decreases when mass is adsorbed on the SWNT surface , giving high mass resolution (tens of atoms in our case). We later found that the electrical conductance is also a function of mass adsorption. 2. Three, two and one layer graphene devices. The graphene layers were obtained by exfoliation and transfered using the polymer stamp technique onto prepared wafers across a trench preplated with platinum electrodes (source and drain). Some wafers had a preplated electrode at the bottom of the trench (local gate), others used the silicon substrate. Three, two and one layer suspended graphene devices with both surfaces exposed, and single layer devices capped on one side with several deposited layers of nBN were fabricated (over 30 devices total). We measured the electrical conductance (G) of the two-terminal devices as a function of adsorbate (Ne, Ar, Kr and Xe), pressure, temperature and current annealing (cleaning) of the devices, and imaged by atomic force microscopy. Cleaning the substrate and impact on previous measurements: We obtained G vs. P isotherms with features which could be exactly correlated to those of the same gases adsorbed on very clean crystalline graphite, after annealing by applying a DC current which heated the suspended center portion (see image). The pressure at which the riser in the isotherm first appeared was two orders of magnitude higher than expected. Final results on physical adsorption were obtained on these cleaned devices. The most likely contaminant is residual organics from processing and organic material present in the atmosphere. These results imply that for 27 or the 30 suspended nanotube devices we studied their surfaces were also totally or partially contaminated. An example of the very high quality phase behavior observed on cleaned graphene is shown in the image. Outcomes: A very accurate measurement of the binding energies of Ar and Kr on SWNT device #30 at very low coverage was obtained by noting the linearity of the mass adsorption (frequency) vs. pressure isotherms over a range of temperatures suitable to each gas. This last year we verified that many of our earlier devices give very close to the same binding energy at coverages below 0.06 monolayer. Cleaned two and three layer graphene devices generate conductance vs. pressure isotherms that can be mapped onto isotherms of the same gases at the same temperatures and pressures on single crystal and exfoliated graphite. The isotherms on single layer graphene devices show, when compared with a single layer graphene capped with nBN, the very small shift in pressures corresponding to the adsorption of gas on both side of the graphene, The extra thickness makes the adsorbed layer on the hBN invisible to the layer adsorbed on the graphene. We obtained several new results: 1. We detected quasi-one-dimensional phase transitions on the surfaces of individual carbon nanotubes 2. We quantified the interactions between the adsorbates and the electrons in the nanotube substrate 3. We measured critical behavior and fluctuations in this quasi-1D system 4. We detected the adsorption and phases of inert molecules absorbed on individual 1-, 2, 3-layer graphene and graphene on hBN substrates using the conductance, which has not been done before 5. We observed a dramatic effect of commensurate phases likely due to coherent scattering of the electrons 6. We constructed the phase diagram of commensurate nitrogen with unprecedented accuracy 7. We detected novel double-layer phases that occur when commensurate arrangements occur simultaneously on both sides of a sheet of suspended graphene, leading to domains and hysteresis 8. We detected the presence of a uniform adsorbed hydrocarbon film on graphene exposed to air which is likely to be omnipresent. Other participants, outreach: Graduate student Joshua Kahn and six undergraduate students also participated in the project. Last Modified: 01/01/2018 Submitted by: David H Cobden
